qas.question: What kind of harmony has Estonian lost?
What language feature does Estonian, Finish and Hungarian share?
In what order are words put in sentences in the Estonian language?
What kind of harmony has Estonian not lost?
What language features do Estonian, Finish and Hungarian differ?
In what order are words put in sentences in the Finnish language?
In what order are words put in sentences in the Hungarian language?
What made it shift from a fusional language to an agglutinative one?

context: Like Finnish and Hungarian, Estonian is a somewhat <a1_0><b4_0>agglutinative<b4_0/><a1_0/> language, but unlike them, it has lost <a0_0>vowel<a0_0/> harmony, the front vowels occurring exclusively on the first or stressed syllable, although in older texts the <b3_0>vowel<b3_0/> harmony can still be recognized. Furthermore, <b7_0>the apocope<b7_0/> of word-final sounds is extensive and has contributed to a shift from a purely agglutinative to a fusional language.[citation needed] The basic word order is <a2_0><b5_0><b6_0>subject–verb–object<b6_0/><b5_0/><a2_0/>.
